pullRequest.title: DHFPROD-4704: Deploy entity model configs after saving an entity
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description

As per @rjrudin's suggestion added the deployment code to the controller since EntityManagerImpl is tightly-coupled to a project filesystem right now.
Deploying the model config only when we update entity model types since that's when the model will have the entity properties.
Moved applyDatabasePropertiesForTests method to the testFixture AbstractHubTest to make it accessible to both core and HC.
Also moved and renamed marklogic-data-hub/src/test/ml-config to marklogic-data-hub/src/test/resources/test-config since test resouces are shared with both core and HC projects.

Checklist:
- Note: do not change the below


Owner:


 JIRA_ID included in all the commit messages


 PR title is in the format JIRA_ID:Title


 Rebase the branch with upstream


 Squashed all commits into a single commit


 Added Tests


Reviewer:


 Reviewed Tests

nodes.bodyText: Yeah I think this is fine here for now. Once we know it's all working correctly, we can consider how to refactor it into DH core and possibly replace parts of EntityManagerImpl with it.

You need to do a try/catch for each individual postJson call. While we only expect one query roleset for now (pii-reader), there could be more in the future. And if the first one fails because it already exists, we still want to try to deploy the others.

Starting with this line, put the rest into a protected method so we can unit-test it easily without depending on ML at all. This is relatively complex logic here, and we want to make sure it behaves correctly. It's easiest to do that if we can pass in our own inputs for the existing dbConfig and the generated indexNode and then verify that they are merged together correctly. Those tests will be much easier to write and will run very quickly - I recommend putting them into a separate test class that doesn't extend anything, can call it "MergeDatabaseConfigTest".
Shouldn't this be a different namespace - isn't this the one that's generated too?
I believe you need to call Installer.applyDatabasePropertiesForTests after each test here because you're modifying the config of the staging/final databases, which could break other tests.

I don't think you should add the database-names here - it's assumed that the client knows what those are, which is the case here. If you were doing it here, you arguably should do it for search-options as well. But I don't think it's necessary - the middle tier has a HubClient, so it's good to go.

nodes.bodyText: Nice. I'm such a big fan of this, because these method names immediately answer a reader's question of - what does it mean to "deploy model configs"? Answer = it means deploying search options, protected paths, query rolesets, and indexes. No comments needed.
Btw, the book Clean Code is very persuasive in arguing for this style
I don't think you need this try/catch here - you've already got a try/catch in the method, that'll catch this error (and it's of course very unlikely that the error will occur).

For future reference - ml-app-deployer has a bunch of POJOs to build this stuff, which is a lot easier to write and read than doing inline JSON in Java. See UpgradeProjectTest for examples of using ElementIndex and Database.

I think you also need a scenario for where the entity indexes already exist. So keep this scenario, and add another one that has the same setup here, and the existing indexes includes the entity indexes.

Food for thought for the future - no change needed now:
"NounTest" - e.g. "ModelControllerTest" - is usually a decent approach for the first couple tests. But that doesn't scale well as the "Noun" becomes able to do more "Verbs". At that points, it's worth refactoring into "Verb1Test", "Verb2Test", etc, and putting them into a package specific to the Noun.
I think ModelControllerTest isn't too big yet, but when we add more tests, it's likely going to be worth moving to a VerbTest approach.
